title: Urea - structure and thermodynamics of dissolution

content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. The compound urea, <math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is widely used in chemical fertilizers. The complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for the urea molecule is shown above. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the carbon atom in the urea molecule.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. The compound urea, <math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is widely used in chemical fertilizers. The complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for the urea molecule is shown above. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the carbon atom in the urea molecule.

(b) Urea has a high solubility in water, due in part to its ability to form hydrogen bonds. A urea molecule and four water molecules are represented in the box below. Draw ONE dashed line (----) to indicate a possible location of a hydrogen bond between a water molecule and the urea molecule.

<math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2, solid, is in equilibrium with, H 2 N C O N H 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> The dissolution of urea is represented by the equation above. A student determines that <math alttext="5.39" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.39</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> grams of <math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="60.06 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60.06</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) can dissolve in water to make <math alttext="5.00 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5.00</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a saturated solution at <math alttext="20 decimal point degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (c) Calculate the concentration of urea, in <math alttext="moles per liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mol/L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the saturated solution at <math alttext="20 decimal point degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The student also determines that the concentration of urea in a saturated solution at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="19.8 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on this information, is the dissolution of urea endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Chatelier’s principle.

(e) The equipment shown above is provided so that the student can determine the value of the molar heat of solution for urea. Knowing that the specific heat of the solution is <math alttext="4.18 joules per gram per degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.18</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J/(g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mo>°</mo><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, list the specific measurements that are required to be made during the experiment.

<math alttext="S naught, in joules per mole per kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>(J/(mol</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K))</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="104.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>104.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2 N C O N H 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NCONH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ? (f) The entropy change for the dissolution of urea, <math alttext="delta S naught of solution " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>soln</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is <math alttext="70.1 joules per mole per kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J/(mol</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using the information in the table above, calculate the absolute molar entropy, <math alttext=" S naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, of aqueous urea.

(g) Using particle-level reasoning, explain why <math alttext="delta S naught of solution " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>soln</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> is positive for the dissolution of urea in water.

(h) The student claims that <math alttext="delta S naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> for the process contributes to the thermodynamic favorability of the dissolution of urea at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the thermodynamic information above to support the student’s claim.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
